ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
The live virtual lectures were recorded and posted to the media library on Canvas for later viewing.
live and recorded lectures
Reading text book - not necessary, but summarizes and reinforces lecture
TA Sessions
The live lectures were also recorded.
Lectures were also recorded and posted after the fact.
Zoom TA hours and recordings of lecture.

Held live lectures that were then also recorded and could be watched back. Because of the odd time most students began just watching the recorded lectures after the first month or so, but the live lectures were still useful if you had a question to ask.
Lectures were recorded and made accessible to students via the Canvas Media Library.
Lectures were live on zoom and most of the class attended. Lectures were also recorded and we could watch them if we couldn't make it to class and reference them when working on homework.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Forces, Friction, Torque, Stresses, Bending, etc.
I learned about the strength and deformation of different materials as used in static mechanics. We analyzed various equilibrium states, friction, stress, strain, shear, bending, and more.
I learned how to analyze physical bodies using engineering tools and math.

Basically the most practical math in MechE. Most topics in the class are based upon force and moment balances. You learn things like how bridges, trusses, and structures are supported, how the parts in simple machines work, and how beams deflect and support loads. Learn to love free body diagrams, because you use them for almost every problem you tackle.
Structural analysis concepts, basic mechanical principals
I learned how to approach a statics problem well.
I learned various different ways to evaluate strengths of materials and solve problems given specific forces.
I enhanced my problem solving skills and critical thinking.
Learned basic statics and material science stuff. Kind of an application of Physics mechanics to engineering things and a good introduction course at that.
I learned about strength of materials, deformation, and strength of structures.
This class is an introduction to analyzing external forces of static structure members (trusses, frames pushing against joints) and then analyzing their internal forces (shear, etc.)
We discussed several applications to mechanical design.

A strong foundation for statics and mechanics concepts. The sum of the forces and moments is zero! I learned how to attack statics and mechanics problems by breaking them up into smaller questions, using methods of sections with equilibrium, and creating additional equations for certain indeterminant problems.
Better understanding of deformation and physics

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The professor was very clear and thorough during lecture. Exams were explained clearly and allowed ample preparation.
Weaknesses: There were mini psets that were only opened after lecture and due the morning after the next lecture. This was difficult for the mid-week psets when I was busy because you only had 2 days to do it. Maybe in the future it would be better to have weekly psets so one could work on them over the weekend or when they have more time.
Lecture participation was low, but the professor was good at teaching the material and providing resources to learn from and study from.

Professor Tarhini did not know the prerequisites of the course nor the required material for future courses. He taught based on his coast guard academy curriculum of a similarly-titled course. He was completely unresponsive and the amazing TA basically ran the class. In addition, he did not go through examples. He scrolled through PDFs of problems that he had completed instead of completing problems in front of us. The class was not conducive to learning. I read the book and watched the recorded lecture at x2 speed in order to learn, but still had to attend class live for participation credit. The whole class arrived and turned their cameras off (apart from 2-3 out of 27 students). He was not engaging at all. Please hire more Yale full time professors for engineering department.

Strengths:
- ultimate, compressive, tensile...
Weaknesses:
- at corners, holes, and joints...

The homework wasnt able to be viewed until after the lecture which made the lecture less helpful. Having the homework available before hand would allow me to come to lecture with questions and to better understand how the concepts we learned in lecture would be applied.
There was not much structure for the exams. Typically exams took way longer than expected
I think the class has strong TAs, but the live lectures are a bit slow and hard to understand. We go over problems, but the professor never writes anything down, so it's hard to follow.
This class, like many of the engineering courses at Yale, varies year to year based on departmental and curriculum changes. However, the course was taught very well for such short notice.
The course teaches important information but the way that it was delivered needs to be improved. A better textbook is needed and more engaging class periods, or more structured recorded lectures.

Had three ish question psets about the lecture due the morning after the next lecture which helped solidify and make sure you knew what was happening in each lecture. Taught kind of from a book and I personally learned a lot online through other sources of information but overall was fine all around. I think different students learned different ways in this class but for me this method worked best. All in all what the course was what you would expect.
It was taught at a quick pace but the lectures were clear and there was great access to help if needed.

This class realistically should have skipped over a significant amount of the material considering the prerequisites.  The first few weeks at least were all things we had learned in physics.  The homework was very relevant and extremely helpful for learning the material.  The office hours system was also very helpful.

Course is just fast enough to be a decent but not overwhelming amount of work. A lot of time was spent going over examples in-lecture, which I'm not a huge fan of, but I think if there was less to go off of as reference the class would be infinitely more difficult.

The live lectures were nice in that we could engage, but at times it was difficult. It might have helped to have more breakout rooms to help with discussion and perhaps a different time slot as for many of us the lectures were right at dinner time.

The lectures were well planned out and easy to follow. I liked how Professor Tarhini gave a lecture on the concepts and then did many example problems during each class, instead of just one or the other. The multitude of example problems (and the extra ones on Canvas) were really helpful for doing the homework and studying for exams. I would have liked more class participation, but that is really hard to enforce. Professor Tarhini did a good job engaging the class and giving opportunities for student responses but it would have been nice if more people would have participated too.
More test feedback

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual office hours were offered at various times of the week to assist with homework/material questions. There was a homework assignment due each class period, so it was helpful to constantly remain engaged with the material and keep up with the topics learned.

Most of class was writing w/ a tablet over zoom and working examples. This was FANTASTIC. People will go to sleep looking at screenshots of the book, and 70% examples 30% concept definition lets you learn a lot more easily. Lots of space to ask questions and help prof work out the problems. Keep that up!
Virtual TA sessions were very helpful, Adam is a great teacher and very patient, also very good at explaining the material in a way that is easy to understand.
I liked that it was a live lecture course.

The lectures worked pretty well, especially since they were recorded for future reference. I think that student interaction with the lectures could be improved. It was very easy to accidentally tune out during the online lecture.
The class in the structure it was did not need to be live. Live Ta hours or review sessions were helpful but the lecture could have been recorded.

Having the live lectures be recorded and uploaded relatively quickly was very helpful, as well as the psets being due after the next class as it made sure you were on top of whatever the current topic was. Learning online was fine.
Virtual office hours went very well

The lectures weren't great.  While Professor Tarhini seems that he would have been a great lecturer any other semester, the zoom format made it much more difficult to follow along with him.  It could have been improved a lot with more emphasis on material during lecture (instead of example problems) and working the example problems out neatly in advance instead of using zoom's whiteboard.
No complaints. Lecture was given live and also recorded. Was a bit dry at times, but that's the best you can do when taking classes online.

Having lectures recorded was incredibly helpful. Professor Tarhini did well with screen sharing problems and solving them on screen and annotating the lecture power point as he gave it. He continuously put in effort to engage the class and get student responses. Often a student would chime in, but it would have been nice if more of the class was participating, but of course that's hard to enforce.
The class was successful in all covid 19 practices

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, the professor did a great job covering the material and the information is especially useful for engineering majors.
Yes, I would recommend this to anyone who enjoyed the mechanics portion of introductory physics and would love to learn more about those topics further.
The course, yes. The professor, no.
Yes! If you're an engineer, ME 280 will feel like gaining half the practical knowledge you need in your future. It's so satisfying to draw out the problems and solve them
I would recommend the course, the foundational concepts we learned were taught very well and I feel like I can apply them to future classes if/when needed.
I would recommend this course, but I think the lectures should be changed.
yes

The course is good. Not too difficult in terms of workload but very dependent on the professor. Professor Tacchini had good intentions for the course but the planning seems to be poor in the twice a week problem sets was not helpful in scheduling working for this class. Overall the content was good to know but slightly repetitive from some of the content pot in mechanical design.

If you have to take it for mechanical engineering you have to and it is fine. If you're really interested in the application of physics mechanics and how forces affect structures and the like and you were good at physics take this course. There was some interesting stuff in the course but only if you are a somewhat math and physics type person. If you dont need the course and dont like math and physics probably dont take the course and I'm not sure why you're even looking at this.
It was definitely a useful and necessary course for an engineer.  I would recommend mechanical engineering students take it.

If you're mechanically-minded this course will probably come naturally to you. Take it for fun. I needed to take 280 for my major anyways, but a few people were in the class just to learn. Don't take it as an extra class if you already have a super-high workload, though. It's interesting but a bit time consuming, like most other MechE classes.

Yes I would recommend this class to mechanical engineering majors. It was significantly better than the statics and mechanics portions of MENG 185. This was a very focused and well planned out class and I believe it is a good preparation for dynamics and further engineering classes.
Yes, it is required for MENG
